title: All inclusive stay at the pearl of the orient

  • If your passport information changes after you make your reservation, please let us know.

overview.content:
Goa, India's tiny paradise, is a mix of Indian and Portuguese cultures, enriched with sun, sea, sand, seafood, and wisdom. Discover Goa's magical charms with your family and friends. The coastline of Goa stretches from point to the point of the state along the Arabian Sea. Many tourists flock to the actual yoga experience and taste delicious cuisine. Even experienced travellers will be taken aback by Goa cuisine's aromas, spices, and flavours.

Reside at the magnificent Alila Diwa and enjoy the ideal blend of Beautiful modern architecture and rich cultural traditions to create a fantastic, unique luxury destination and unforgettable experiences.

Book today to take a break from work, engage with family, relax, enjoy a significant occasion, or solely chill. Our Holiday Vibes are Good Vibes Only!

hotels.name: Alila Diwa Goa
hotels.description:
The five-star Alila Diwa Goa resort is in Majorda, South Goa. Relax in India's most excellent Infinity Pools and enjoy breathtaking sunsets. A separate Kids' Pool with views of lush green paddy fields is also available. The wellness centre that provides western, traditional, and Ayurvedic spa services, the Diwa Club by Alila is a resort inside a resort that offers privacy and exclusivity. It also offers a gym open 24 hours a day and a yoga studio with free yoga classes. In the rooms and public areas, all guests have complimentary Wi-Fi access. 

The vast and stylishly constructed rooms and suites include a king-size bed with a foam mattress, a private sit-out, a stand-alone shower, a walk-in wardrobe, and a separate workplace besides these facilities. 

There are three eateries and two bars, including Vivo, an all-day cafe, a poolside bar, and a nightclub on edge. There is also a Courtyard Bar, an evening cocktail bar, and Spice Studio. A magnificent Tree House is placed on an old tree for a quiet and personal dining experience.

destination.name: Goa
destination.title: Holidays To Goa

image.alt: Goa Vibes, best travel destinations in India - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• There is plenty to see and do before relaxing on the beach, with a long colonial heritage and a UNESCO-listed old city.
  • For more than 400 years, it was a Portuguese colony, and those influences are intertwined with Indian culture to create a one-of-a-kind paradise.
  • The 66-mile coastline offers a relaxed atmosphere as the Arabian Sea laps against India's western coastline, attracting two million tourists each year.
  • Goa, best known for its white sands, demonstrates the tropical side of India while also housing some fascinating history.
  • The smallest state in India has something for everyone, from the busy north to Old Goa to the relaxing south.
  • The Portuguese heritage serves as a backdrop to a long, opulent coastline in a region rich in character and charm.
  • The choice is yours: relax by a beach shack, surrounded by golden sands and dipping your feet in the water, or immerse yourself in colonial history, attend vibrant markets, and see some wildlife.
  • While the beaches are private and relaxed, the state is traditional and conservative, so when going on day trips or visits, dress comfortably but respectfully.
  • To have a fantastic experience with the best of this city, make sure to check off some of the highlights listed in our top 10 reasons to visit Goa.
     
  • Capital- Panaji 
  • International Airport- Dabolim International Airport (GOI) 
  • Population- 1.6 Million  
  • Currency- Indian rupee   
  • Time:  UTC +5:30  
  • Driving side- left   
  • Official Language- Konkani  
  • Religion-Hinduism and Christianity
images.imageAlt: Best holidays to Goa with World Holiday Vibes - Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• Panaji, nestled along the banks of the broad Mandovi River, is a laid-back city where the delightful old Portuguese districts of Fontainhas and Sao Tomé are ideal for a lazy afternoon of wandering.
  • South Indian spices – black pepper, cloves, cardamom, tamarind – were a major draw for the seafaring Portuguese, and today a fun day trip away from the beach is to one of several commercial spice plantations orbiting Ponda or further south at the Tanshikar Spice Farm.
  • Whether you're looking for serious souvenirs or just a taste of local life, Goa's many markets are a must-see. The most well-known is Anjuna's flea market, which has been held every Wednesday in season since the 1970s.
  • Downward-dog your way through the days in lovely, laid-back Mandrem, where an early morning yoga class followed by a refreshing swim, an afternoon on a sun lounge with a good book, and perhaps an ayurvedic massage are ideal for your spiritual soul.
  • Old Goa, the 17th-century Portuguese capital, rivaled Lisbon and London in size and importance, and was widely known as the "Rome of the East."
  • Palolem is a popular destination for travellers from all over the world due to its blissful crescent of golden sand, balmy seas, gently swaying palm trees, good food, beach huts galore, and a vibrant backpacker-oriented beach bar scene.
  • Goa's forests and wildlife reserves have a lot to offer nature lovers, though most large animals are difficult to spot. Avid birdwatchers will enjoy Dr Salim Ali Bird Sanctuary, Bondla Wildlife Sanctuary, and the many other excellent locations in Goa.
  • Cruising Goa's back roads and beach villages on two wheels is practically mandatory. At any of Goa's beaches, you can rent a moped or a thumping Royal Enfield motorcycle for a few dollars per day.
  • Frothy Dudhsagar, which translates as "Sea of Milk," is India's second-highest waterfall (after Jog Falls in Karnataka) and a fantastic day-trip adventure.
  • The Konkan Railway, which connects Mumbai and Mangalore and passes through Goa, is one of India's great railway journeys. Although flying is faster, the romance of the rails is still alive and well here.
images.imageAlt: Highlights of Goa, top-rated tourist attractions & best things to do - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• Goa is a year-round destination; it is frequently used as the final stop on a tour of India, and it is also popular with sun worshippers all year.
  • The temperature remains consistent throughout the year, with May being the hottest month with an average of 30oC and January being the coldest month with averages of 25oC.
  • The monsoon season, which begins in June, is often avoided by visitors because the hot summer temperatures meet the clouds and rain, transforming the countryside of Goa into a lush green space ideal for colorful plant life.
  • Although not ideal for the beach, it transforms the state into a wonderful haven for other activities.
  • Even though the temperatures drop in the evenings, it is never cold.
  • The tourist season is noticeable here and lasts from October to January, with the beaches filling up again in May for the warmest weather.
images.imageAlt: Best time to visit Goa - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• Beaches are a prominent feature of Goa's attractions, helping to make it one of the best places to visit in India.
  • Almost every tourist who visits the area spends a day at Palolem Beach, a crescent-shaped stretch of white sand in south Goa that overlooks the Arabian Sea.
  • While simply relaxing and taking in the scenery is a great way to enjoy this beautiful area, Palolem Beach also has a variety of activities to keep you busy.
  • Kayaking, yoga classes, dolphin-sightseeing trips, and swimming are all options.
  • You can also spend the night in one of Palolem's rustic coco huts, which are built at the beginning of the high season.
  • Colva Beach is another popular tourist destination in Goa, particularly among Indians.
  • It has swaying palms and a long stretch of bronze sand, where herds of cows sunbathe alongside tourists.
  • You can rent Jet Skis, take a thrilling banana boat ride, or parasail for a bird's-eye view of the beach.
images.imageAlt: Popular beaches in Goa - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• While many tourists come to Goa for the beaches, many others come to visit important religious sites such as the Basilica de Bom Jesus.
  • This Old Goa attraction dates from the late 16th century and houses the St. Francis Xavier's remains.
  • The "Apostle of the Indies" co-founded the Society of Jesus religious order with friend St. Ignatius Loyola and led a large mission in India.
  • Since 1999, the basilica has been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
  • The simple yet imposing structure is a combination of Doric, Corinthian, and Baroque styles, with intricate carvings.
  • Surprisingly, the church was stripped of its lime plaster in the mid-twentieth century, making it Goa's only church without plaster.
  • Monsoons have since worn down the Basilica de Bom Jesus.
  • You can tour the church on your own or pay a small fee to hire one of the independent guides near the entrance.
  • Inside, there are massive ornamental screens and the body of the resident saint in a casket covered in precious stones.
  • It's a captivating location that will transport you back in time.
  • The Feast of St. Francis Xavier draws large crowds to this church every year in late November and early December.
  • It begins with a nine-day novena and open-air masses and concludes with the major holiday on December 3.
images.imageAlt: Basilica de Bom jesus in Goa - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.imageTitle: Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception
images.description:
• Visit another of Goa's historic churches, the Church of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception, in the laid-back city of Panaji.
  • The pristine white church, which dates from the early 17th century, is perched atop a zigzagging staircase resembling the tiers of a wedding cake.
  • Its perfectly symmetrical Portuguese Baroque architecture is stunning.
  • At night, twinkle lights transform the church into something out of a fairy tale.
  • While not ornate, the church's interior is bright and colorful.
  • Tourists can view the elegant main altar (dedicated to Mary, Jesus' mother) and the gilded pillars with intricate carvings.
  • Around various holidays, blue and white blossom vines adorn parts of the vaulted ceiling.
  • The Festival of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception, celebrated on December 8, is a major holiday at this church.
  • Swing by to see it decked out in a slew of bright lights.
images.imageAlt: Our lady of the immaculate conception in Goa - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• These three adjoining beaches are among the closest to the airport and are conveniently linked by local bus to each other and the regional hub of Margao.
  • This is a great area for cycling, with flat paths lined by palm groves and away from the main road (and hotels often rent bikes).
  • Among the few high-end resorts are some likeable mid-range hotels and an agreeable but limited range of facilities, such as the typical bamboo cafés on the sand.
  • Some sections of the beaches are surprisingly deserted, while others are so undeveloped that the accommodations are nestled among buffalo farms.
images.imageAlt: Utorda, Majorda, & Betalbatim, best beaches  in Goa - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• The laid-back feel and village vibe of Colva, popular since the Hippy Trail of the 1960s, are gradually receding each year as it becomes more developed.
  • Despite the fact that it is now dominated by mid-range resorts with plenty of space and gardens, Colva is not as crowded as Calangute or Baga due to development restrictions imposed by meandering roads.
  • Benaulim's quieter – and sometimes deserted – stretches of beach are a little further south.
  • Both areas also have a limited selection of water sports.
images.imageAlt: Colva & Benaulim in Goa - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• These adjoining beaches are sprinkled with top-end resorts midway along the southern coast, with some offering adorable brightly-painted bungalows among vast gardens as close to the beach as possible.
  • The main road through Cavelossim has a wide range of amenities and is only a short walk from the river (where boat trips are available).
  • The dead-end road south to Mobor's almost Crusoe-esque beach is flat and quiet, making it ideal for cycling. (Some hotels provide bicycle rentals.)
  • The fact that the main road connecting both areas is accessible via the reliable bus service is an added bonus.
images.imageAlt: Cavelossim & Mobor in Goa - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• Old Goa (about 10km away) is the official name for the former Goan capital, which is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
  • It is not to be confused with the old section of the state capital, Panaji (see above).
  • The majority of the 30,000 inhabitants fled centuries ago during a malaria outbreak, and the remainder abandoned the city when the river silted up, so the colonial-era capital was relocated to Panaji in the mid-nineteenth century.
  • The compact area of Old Goa is lined with ruins of churches, cathedrals, and forts that are beyond repair, as well as the fantastic Basilica de Bom Jesus and Sé Cathedral.
  • The variety of accommodations is limited, but Old Goa is a short day trip from Panaji and has several lovely old-fashioned guesthouses.
images.imageAlt: Old Goa - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

images.description:
• Goa, a former Portuguese colony, is also known as the "Rome of the East."
  • Goa's culture is distinct from the rest of the country, having been inhabited and colonized by the Portuguese for nearly 450 years.
  • Here's a quick rundown of Goa's rich and diverse heritage.
  • The performing arts are especially popular among Goans.
  • Goan dances, which are a beautiful blend of Indian and Western dance forms, include Fugdi, Dhalo, and the Kunbi, which date back to the Portuguese era in Goa.
  • Folk dances and music are performed in the state for both religious festivals and joyful events.
  • This dance form is performed while wearing a ghumat and is accompanied by a song with western roots, despite the dance's Indian origins.
  • The Dekhni dance, which is only performed by women in the community, is one of Goa's most well-known traditions.
  • These are two Goan dance forms that are typically performed during the spring months as an offering and jubilation for the bounty that the season brings to the peasants and their crops.
  • The Goff consists of weaving braids with various tints of color and is commonly performed by residents of Goa's Canacona Taluka (province).
  •  Shigmo is distinguished by traditional dances performed in colorful costumes to the beats of dhol, tasha, or cymbals.
  • Processions of floats on which passionate actors enact performances depicting Goa's history can be seen on Goa's streets.
images.imageAlt: Goa Culture & Traditions - World Holiday Vibes, Good Vibes Only

destination.countryContent:
Holidays in India are a feast of senses, with beaches bordered by the Indian Ocean, bustling but mesmerising towns, marble-covered castles, and Kerala's coconut coastline. The energy and spirit that dances across India may be felt from the first burst of patchouli-infused balmy air to the second or third odd sight of a cow ambling along the road on your rickshaw ride into Delhi. A stunning sunrise scenery of the Taj Mahal and the mesmerising first look of the pink city of Jaipur is also present. 

India holidays are all inclusive; one moment, you can indulge in delectable street food in Mumbai. Next, you can enjoy a culinary feast in Udaipur; one day, you can experience a cacophony of vibrant markets, sacred statues, and Hindu temples; the next, you can spend a quiet afternoon cruising the backwaters of Kerala. Imagine grand hotels coated in cool marble, Mughal emperors' cities, uncharted rural areas where you can drink chai with locals, and Rajasthan's bustling but beautiful cities. Our carefully curated trips to India take you on tour through its rich cultural diversity, from its most striking landmarks to its more remote regions. Our Holiday Vibes are Good Vibes Only!
destination.cheapHolidayDescription: Goa is a beautiful travel city for families with small children, teenagers, or all of the above due to its fascinating and diverse culture. Goa’s cuisine is flavourful, nutritious, and relatively straightforward, and the most famous dishes among visitors are Vindoola, Goan Sausages, Dodl and Bebinca. Goa uses the Indian Rupee as its official currency. While there isn't a dress code in Goa, it's vital to observe the standards while visiting places of worship and it is advised to dress modestly and respectfully, keeping in mind cultural sensitivity. Local Buses and Auto-rickshaw are Goa’s most affordable modes of travel. The beauty of the city and the popular locations to visit will make your holiday a worthwhile journey. Our Flight Vibes are Good Vibes Only!
